splits.name: petscii_overview
splits.description: Overview of PETSCII: definition (PET Standard Code of Information Interchange), used by the Commodore 64 and other Commodore computers; explains that the table lists all 256 PETSCII codes with decimal/hex values and character descriptions; notes how the character column shows both uppercase/graphics (up/gfx) and lowercase/uppercase (lo/up) modes.

references.topic: special notes about control ranges and unused codes
how PETSCII maps to screen codes used in video memory
screen codes used in $0400-$07E7

splits.name: petscii_notes
splits.description: Important notes about PETSCII behavior and special cases: control code ranges ($00-$1F and $80-$9F) are layout/control codes, codes $60-$7F and $E0-$FE are copies of other codes ($C0-$DF and $A0-$BE), and code $FF is a BASIC token for the pi symbol with special internal conversions to/from $DE. Explains keyboard buffer behaviour for $DE.

references.topic: detailed behavior of code $FF and conversion to $DE
control codes $00-$1F examples
control codes $80-$9F examples

splits.name: petscii_control_00_1f
splits.description: PETSCII control codes in ranges $00-$1F (decimal 0-31). Lists each code's decimal and hex value with description including: unused codes, Stop (RUN/STOP $03), color set White ($05), Disable/Enable Commodore-Shift ($08/$09), Return ($0D), switch charset to lowercase/uppercase ($0E), Cursor Down ($11), Reverse On ($12), Home ($13), Delete ($14), Red ($1C), Cursor Right ($1D), Green ($1E), Blue ($1F).

splits.name: petscii_printable_20_3f
splits.description: PETSCII printable characters in range $20-$3F (decimal 32-63). Covers space, punctuation, and digits 0-9, plus symbols : ; < = > ? with decimal/hex values listed for each code.

references.topic: conversion: PETSCII $20-$3F map directly to Screen Code $20-$3F

splits.name: petscii_letters_40_5f
splits.description: PETSCII letters and symbols in range $40-$5F (decimal 64-95). Describes behavior in both character set modes: in uppercase/graphics mode these are uppercase letters/symbols; in lowercase/uppercase mode these are lowercase letters (a-z) and symbols. Table entries include @, A-Z, bracket/arrow symbols and their codes ($40-$5F).

references.topic: conversion: PETSCII $40-$5F -> Screen Code $00-$1F (subtract $40)
the screen codes that represent @ and letters ($00-$1F)

splits.name: petscii_graphic_or_upper_60_7f
splits.description: PETSCII codes $60-$7F (decimal 96-127): in uppercase/graphics mode these are graphic characters (identical to $C0-$DF), in lowercase/uppercase mode they are uppercase letters (same as $C0-$DF). Notes that codes $60-$7F are copies of $C0-$DF and lists the entries, including horizontal line, graphic characters and Pi symbol copies.

references.topic: original graphic character definitions in $C0-$DF (which $60-$7F copy)
conversion: PETSCII $60-$7F -> Screen Code $40-$5F (subtract $20)

splits.name: petscii_control_80_9f
splits.description: PETSCII control codes in range $80-$9F (decimal 128-159). Lists each control: color set codes (e.g. Orange $81), Run ($83), function keys F1-F8 encoded in PETSCII ($85-$8C, order noted), Shift-Return ($8D), switch charset to uppercase/graphics ($8E), Cursor Up ($91), Reverse Off ($92), Clear ($93), Insert ($94), various color codes ($90, $95-$9F), and cursor direction ($9D Cursor Left).

references.topic: color-setting control codes in $80-$9F (e.g. $81 Orange)
canonical summary of control actions across ranges

splits.name: petscii_graphic_a0_bf
splits.description: PETSCII graphic characters in range $A0-$BF (decimal 160-191). Lists graphic symbol names and descriptions used in graphics mode (e.g. Shift-Space non-breaking/solid space $A0, CBM-K $A1, diagonal lines and corner pieces, quarter/full blocks, spade/suit, arrows, and other CBM-specific graphics), with decimal and hex codes.

screen code positions for these graphic characters ($60-$7F)

splits.name: petscii_graphic_c0_df
splits.description: PETSCII graphic characters / uppercase letters in range $C0-$DF (decimal 192-223). Describes that in uppercase/graphics mode these are graphic characters and in lowercase/uppercase mode they are uppercase letters. Lists the graphic characters (horizontal line, many CBM graphics) and copies of letters/symbols (A-Z and special symbols) in $C0-$DF.

references.topic: copies located at $60-$7F
conversion: PETSCII $C0-$DF -> Screen Code $40-$5F (subtract $80)

splits.name: petscii_graphic_e0_fe
splits.description: PETSCII graphic characters in range $E0-$FE (decimal 224-254). Notes that codes $E0-$FE are copies of $A0-$BE and enumerates the copied graphic characters (Shift-Space, CBM-K etc.) with their corresponding original $A0-$BE code references.

references.topic: original definitions for $A0-$BF which $E0-$FE copy

splits.name: petscii_ff_special
splits.description: Special-case PETSCII code $FF (decimal 255): documented as the BASIC token for the pi symbol. Describes internal conversion behavior: $FF is converted to $DE when printed; $DE is converted back to $FF when fetched from the screen; when reading the keyboard buffer $DE is returned for Shift-up arrow (no conversion performed at that stage).

references.topic: the Pi symbol graphic at $DE in $C0-$DF
overview notes mentioning $FF special handling

splits.name: petscii_to_screen_conversion
splits.description: Conversion rules between PETSCII and C64 Screen Codes (screen memory $0400-$07E7). Gives explicit mapping formulas: PETSCII $20-$3F -> Screen $20-$3F (unchanged); $40-$5F -> Screen $00-$1F (subtract $40); $60-$7F -> Screen $40-$5F (subtract $20); $A0-$BF -> Screen $60-$7F (subtract $40); $C0-$DF -> Screen $40-$5F (subtract $80). Also notes to add $80 to a screen code to get its reverse-video equivalent.

references.topic: screen codes used in screen memory ($0400-$07E7)
how to obtain reverse video by adding $80 to screen codes
unchanged mapping for $20-$3F (space/digits/symbols)

splits.name: screen_codes_intro
splits.description: Introduction to Commodore 64 Screen Codes (source reference). Explains that screen codes are the values stored in screen memory ($0400-$07E7) and differ from PETSCII; explains display modes up/gfx and lo/up; notes that codes $80-$FF are reverse-video equivalents (bit 7 set) of $00-$7F.

references.topic: how PETSCII maps to screen codes
reverse-video mapping and examples

splits.name: screen_codes_at_and_letters_00_1f
splits.description: Screen codes $00-$1F (decimal 0-31): represent @ and the uppercase letters A-Z (or lowercase in lo/up mode). Lists each screen code with the character it displays: $00 = @, $01 = A / a, up to $1A = Z / z, plus [, pound sign, ], up arrow, left arrow at the upper codes.

references.topic: PETSCII $40-$5F convert to these screen codes (subtract $40)

splits.name: screen_codes_space_digits_symbols_20_3f
splits.description: Screen codes $20-$3F (decimal 32-63): space, punctuation, and digits 0-9, plus symbols : ; < = > ? with each screen code listed by decimal and hex.

references.topic: these screen codes directly correspond to PETSCII $20-$3F

splits.name: screen_codes_graphic_or_upper_40_5f
splits.description: Screen codes $40-$5F (decimal 64-95): in uppercase/graphics mode these display graphic characters; in lowercase/uppercase mode they display uppercase letters A-Z and some symbols. Lists entries $40-$5F including horizontal line, graphic characters and the mapping to letters when in lo/up mode.

splits.name: screen_codes_graphic_60_7f
splits.description: Screen codes $60-$7F (decimal 96-127): graphic characters in both character set modes. Includes non-breaking/solid space ($60), CBM-K, diagonal and corner graphics, half/quarter blocks, spade symbol, vertical/horizontal lines, and other CBM graphics with each corresponding screen code listed.

splits.name: petscii_color_codes_summary
splits.description: Summary of PETSCII control codes that set text color and their corresponding color names and decimal/hex values. Lists the control codes for the C64 16-color palette: White $05 (dec 5), Red $1C, Green $1E, Blue $1F, Orange $81, Black $90, Brown $95, Pink $96, Dark Grey $97, Grey $98, Light Green $99, Light Blue $9A, Light Grey $9B, Purple $9C, Yellow $9E, Cyan $9F. Notes these correspond to VIC-II color values 0-15.

splits.name: petscii_control_codes_summary
splits.description: Concise summary table of frequently used PETSCII control codes and their actions with decimal/hex values. Includes Stop (RUN/STOP $03), Disable/Enable Commodore-Shift ($08/$09), Return ($0D), switch charsets ($0E/$8E), Cursor Down/Up ($11/$91), Reverse On/Off ($12/$92), Home ($13), Delete ($14), Cursor Right/Left ($1D/$9D), Run ($83), function-key tokens (e.g. F1 $85, F3 $86, etc.), Shift-Return $8D, Clear Screen $93, Insert $94, and others.
